Package mz

Class WeaveMerge

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Merge
mz.WeaveMerge
All Implemented Interfaces:
MergeInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>
Direct Known Subclasses:
IntroWeaveMerge
public class WeaveMerge extends Merge
Weave Merge Sort is a variation of the Merge Sort algorithm that aims to achieve better performance by reducing the number of array copies during the merging step. In Weave Merge Sort, instead of creating a new merged array, the merging process is performed directly on the original array. This is achieved by using additional subarrays, left array and right array, to store the elements from the original array temporarily.
Since:
1.0
Author:
Magyar Zolt√°n

  • Constructor Details

    • WeaveMerge

      public WeaveMerge()
      Weave Merge Sort:
      Is a variation of the Merge Sort algorithm that aims to achieve better performance by reducing the number of array copies during the merging step. In Weave Merge Sort, instead of creating a new merged array, the merging process is performed directly on the original array. This is achieved by using additional subarrays, left array and right array, to store the elements from the original array temporarily.

      Example:
      1. The method takes an array, a left index, and a right index as parameters.
      2. It calculates the size of the range to be sorted and stores it in the variable n.
      3. If the size n is less than or equal to 1, the range is already sorted, so the method returns.
      4. Otherwise, it calculates the middle index of the range and stores it in the variable mid.
      5. Two new subarrays, left Array and right Array, are created using Arrays.copyOfRange. left Array contains the elements from the array parameter starting from the left index up to (but not including) the middle index. right Array contains the elements from the middle index up to (but not including) the right index.
      6. The method then calls itself recursively twice. The first recursive call sorts the left subarray by passing the range from the left index to the middle index. The second recursive call sorts the right subarray by passing the range from the middle index to the right index.
      7. After the recursive calls, passing the original array, left Array, and right Array as parameters. This helper method performs the merging step by comparing elements from left Array and right Array and placing them in the correct order in the original array.
      8. The recursion continues until the base case is reached, which occurs when the range to be sorted has a size of 1 or less. At this point, the recursive calls stop, and the sorting process is complete.
      Note:
      By performing the merging step directly on the original array, Weave Merge Sort eliminates the need for creating a new merged array at each recursion level, reducing the number of array copies and potentially improving the performance of the sorting algorithm.

      It's important to note that the efficiency of the Weave Merge Sort algorithm is still determined by the same asymptotic complexity as the standard Merge Sort algorithm, which is O(n log(n)) in the average and worst cases, where n is the number of elements in the array.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Average Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Auxiliary Space: O(n)
      Stability: Yes
      See Also:
      • IntroDPQWeakHeap
      • IntroWeaveMerge

    • weaveMergeInc

      protected void weaveMergeInc(Comparable[] array)
      weaveMergeInc that performs a weave merge sort algorithm to sort a Comparable array in ascending order.
      • It first calculates the size of the range to be sorted by subtracting 0 from array.length, storing the result in the variable n.
      • If the size n is less than or equal to 1, it means the range has at most one element or is empty, so there's nothing to sort, and the method returns.
      • If the range has more than one element, the method proceeds to calculate the middle index of the range to half of n. The result is stored in the variable mid.
      • The method then creates two new arrays: leftArray and rightArray. They are created using Arrays.copyOfRange, which creates a new array containing the elements from the array parameter starting from index 0 (inclusive) and ending at index mid (exclusive) for leftArray, and starting from index mid (inclusive) and ending at index n (exclusive) for rightArray.
      • After creating the 0 and n subarrays, the method calls itself recursively twice: once with the range from 0 to mid, and once with the range from mid to n. This recursive step is responsible for recursively dividing the array into smaller subarrays until the base case (n <= 1) is reached.
      • Finally, the method calls another helper method mergingInc to merge the sorted leftArray and rightArray back into the original array, effectively sorting the entire range from 0 to n in ascending order.
      weaveMergeInc method modifies the original array in place rather than returning a new sorted array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be sorted.
      See Also:
      • MergeInterface.mergingInc(Comparable[], Comparable[], Comparable[])

    • weaveMergeDec

      protected void weaveMergeDec(Comparable[] array)
      weaveMergeDec that performs a weave merge sort algorithm to sort a Comparable array in descending order.
      • It first calculates the size of the range to be sorted by subtracting 0 from array.length, storing the result in the variable n.
      • If the size n is less than or equal to 1, it means the range has at most one element or is empty, so there's nothing to sort, and the method returns.
      • If the range has more than one element, the method proceeds to calculate the middle index of the range to half of n. The result is stored in the variable mid.
      • The method then creates two new arrays: leftArray and rightArray. They are created using Arrays.copyOfRange, which creates a new array containing the elements from the array parameter starting from index 0 (inclusive) and ending at index mid (exclusive) for leftArray, and starting from index mid (inclusive) and ending at index n (exclusive) for rightArray.
      • After creating the 0 and n subarrays, the method calls itself recursively twice: once with the range from 0 to mid, and once with the range from mid to n. This recursive step is responsible for recursively dividing the array into smaller subarrays until the base case (n <= 1) is reached.
      • Finally, the method calls another helper method mergingDec to merge the sorted leftArray and rightArray back into the original array, effectively sorting the entire range from 0 to n in descending order.
      weaveMergeInc method modifies the original array in place rather than returning a new sorted array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be sorted.
      See Also:
      • MergeInterface.mergingInc(Comparable[], Comparable[], Comparable[])

    • weaveMergeInc

      protected void weaveMergeInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      weaveMergeInc that performs a weave merge sort algorithm to sort a Comparable array in ascending order.
      • It first calculates the size of the range to be sorted by subtracting left from right, storing the result in the variable n.
      • If the size n is less than or equal to 1, it means the range has at most one element or is empty, so there's nothing to sort, and the method returns.
      • If the range has more than one element, the method proceeds to calculate the middle index of the range by adding left to half of n. The result is stored in the variable mid.
      • The method then creates two new arrays: leftArray and rightArray. They are created using Arrays.copyOfRange, which creates a new array containing the elements from the array parameter starting from index left (inclusive) and ending at index mid (exclusive) for leftArray, and starting from index mid (inclusive) and ending at index right (exclusive) for rightArray.
      • After creating the left and right subarrays, the method calls itself recursively twice: once with the range from left to mid, and once with the range from mid to right. This recursive step is responsible for recursively dividing the array into smaller subarrays until the base case (n <= 1) is reached.
      • Finally, the method calls another helper method mergingInc to merge the sorted leftArray and rightArray back into the original array, effectively sorting the entire range from left to right in ascending order.
      weaveMergeInc method modifies the original array in place rather than returning a new sorted array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be sorted.
      left - index representing the start of the range to be sorted.
      right - index representing the end of the range to be sorted.
      See Also:
      • MergeInterface.mergingInc(Comparable[], Comparable[], Comparable[])

    • weaveMergeDec

      protected void weaveMergeDec(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      weaveMergeDec that performs a weave merge sort algorithm to sort a Comparable array in descending order.
      • It first calculates the size of the range to be sorted by subtracting left from right, storing the result in the variable n.
      • If the size n is less than or equal to 1, it means the range has at most one element or is empty, so there's nothing to sort, and the method returns.
      • If the range has more than one element, the method proceeds to calculate the middle index of the range by adding left to half of n. The result is stored in the variable mid.
      • The method then creates two new arrays: leftArray and rightArray. They are created using Arrays.copyOfRange, which creates a new array containing the elements from the array parameter starting from index left (inclusive) and ending at index mid (exclusive) for leftArray, and starting from index mid (inclusive) and ending at index right (exclusive) for rightArray.
      • After creating the left and right subarrays, the method calls itself recursively twice: once with the range from left to mid, and once with the range from mid to right. This recursive step is responsible for recursively dividing the array into smaller subarrays until the base case (n <= 1) is reached.
      • Finally, the method calls another helper method mergingDec to merge the sorted leftArray and rightArray back into the original array, effectively sorting the entire range from left to right in descending order.
      weaveMergeDec method modifies the original array in place rather than returning a new sorted array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be sorted.
      left - index representing the start of the range to be sorted.
      right - index representing the end of the range to be sorted.
